abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the National Seeds
            Project (NSP) for Guinea was unsatisfactory. The project
            failed to achieve its main objectives, institutional
            development was negligible, sustainability is unlikely, and
            the performance of the Bank was unsatisfactory while the
            Borrower's was marginally satisfactory. Several lessons
            can be learned from this project. First, any new large scale
            activity should be preceded by and tested in a pilot
            operation. Second, agricultural support services
            interventions should be sequenced in a logical manner. In
            the NSP, production and marketing activities should have
            been undertaken only after an apparent increase was seen in
            the demand for improved seeds and the use of complementary
            farm inputs. Third, private operators should be involved
            from the outset in a project aimed at developing the private
            sector. Finally, Borrower commitment to the project is
            essential for successful implementation and achievement of
            project objectives. In the NSP, success was compromised by
            the Government's failure to replace NSP's weak
            management and provide counterpart funds in a timely manner.
